thread.title_full: Turn-back boat policy likely as Bill Shorten cobbles together shaky deal | The Advertiser

author: Samantha Maiden, wires
title: Turn-back boat policy likely as Bill Shorten cobbles together shaky deal | The
text:
BILL Shorten faces a showdown on his demand Labor supports a turn back policy for the asylum seeker boats, with the Left faction formally supporting a vote on whether to ban the practice.
After emotional meetings of delegates to the ALP’s 47th conference today the bitter divisions will be put to the floor of the conference this afternoon.
The Labor leader is personally calling delegates as he fights to secure a victory on the issue that critics warn could scuttle his leadership if he is defeated on the floor of the ALP conference.
Labor MPs are confident he will prevail on the issue despite splintering in both factions.
The Left and the Right have split on the issue with Left frontbencher Tanya Plibersek backing Bill Shorten against the move to humiliate him over the divisive issue.
The Left will not be binding their delegates to vote against boat turn backs assuring Mr Shorten of a likely narrow victory.
Labor frontbencher Anthony Albanese has publicly voiced his opposition to turn backs arguing it could be tough on border protection without being weak on humanity.
Mr Albanese did not speak at this morning’s Left faction meeting.
There are some in the Right faction including Victorian Michael Donovan raising concerns about Mr Shorten’s position in factional talks.
Shadow immigration minister Richard Marles was heckled at the forum. Picture: AAP Source: AAP
Addressing the conference earlier today Mr Shorten said he believes in a new direction for the party’s immigration policy, including boat turn backs where they are safe to do so.
He said he wanted to accept more refugees and ensure they are treated more humanely.
“I also want to guarantee that we keep closed the lethal journey between Java and Christmas Island which has already claimed sadly so many lives,” he said.
Mr Shorten said the asylum seeker issue was a question of “profound significance” for Labor and Australia and he wanted conference delegates to offer “every view” in Saturday afternoon’s debate.
“But we must never allow people smugglers to take advantage of a perceived weakness and so ... a Labor government, I believe, must have the option of turning back boats, turning them around, provided it is safe to do so.”
He said by 2025 a Labor government would double Australia’s annual humanitarian refugee intake to 27,000 people.
Mr Shorten also announced independent oversight of detention centres, the return of UN protections to the Migration Act, mandatory reporting of child abuse in facilities and a $450 million contribution over three years to the UN high commissioner for refugees.
Mr Shorten said the plan would ensure refugees were treated with greater dignity and humanity.
“I did not enter politics to shirk hard issues and hard decisions. I stand here determined for our country to be responsible in the world and secure at home, determined for us to be a welcoming, kind, compassionate and safe destination, and determined that Labor will achieve this for Australia,” he said.
Originally published as Shorten faces boat showdown
